facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 198 and 199 of 1963 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 198 and 199 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated February 4, 1963, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 779 and 780 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeals from the judgment and order dated February 4, 1963, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 779 780 of 1962.

facts.text: High Court affirmed the order of acquittal passed against the respondent by the Judicial Magistrate, A First Class, Vadagaon Mawal.

anchor.surface_text: By this judgment the High Court affirmed the order of  N 4SCI-3 acquittal passed against the respondent by the Judicial Magistrate, A First Class, Vadagaon  Mawal .

facts.text: Labour Inspector Central, Bombay-1, appointed under the Minimum Wages Act XI of 1948 by the Central Government filed two complaints.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are as follows The Labour Inspector  Central , Bombay-1, appointed under the Minimum Wages Act  XI of 1948   hereinafter called the Act  by the Central Government filed two companyplaints

facts.text: Complaints alleged that the respondent contravened certain provisions of the Minimum Wages Central Rules, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate alleging that the respondent had companytravened certain provisions of the Minimum Wages  Central  Rules, 1950.

facts.text: Respondent was doing quarrying operation work in quarry survey Nos. 23 1 Kusegaon village near Lonavala.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the respondent was doing quarrying operation work in quarry survey Nos. 23 1  Kusegaon village near Lonavala, and while carrying on this quarrying operation work

facts.text: Respondent failed to observe certain provisions in the Rules while carrying on quarrying operation work.

anchor.surface_text: he, failed to observe certain provisions in the Rules. The respondent submitted a written statement admitting the facts

facts.text: Respondent submitted a written statement admitting the facts.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent submitted a written statement admitting the facts but he companytended, inter alia, that the Inspector was number authorised

facts.text: Respondent contended that the Inspector was not authorised to file the complaint.

anchor.surface_text: but he companytended, inter alia, that the Inspector was number authorised to file the companyplaint and it was only an inspector appointed by the Maharashtra State

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate treated the contention as a preliminary objection.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Magistrate, treating this as a preliminary objection, came to the companyclusion that the Inspector was number entitled to file the companyplaint.

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate concluded that the word mine in sub-cl. i of s. 2(b) of the Act does not include a stone quarry.

anchor.surface_text: According to him, the word mine in sub-cl.  i  of s. 2 b  of the Act does number include a stone quarry and, therefore, the appropriate Government was the State Government and number the Central Government.

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate acquitted the accused of the offence under s. 22A, read with s. 18, of the Act and for contravening certain rules of the Minimum Wages Central Rules, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: There upon he acquitted the accused of the offence under s. 22A, read with s. 18, of the Act and for companytravening certain rules of the Minimum Wages  Central  Rules, 1950.

facts.text: The State filed two appeals before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The State then filed two appeals before the High Court. The High Court also came to the companyclusion

facts.text: High Court concluded that the Inspector was not competent to file the complaints.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also came to the companyclusion that the Inspector was number companypetent to file the companyplaints but the reasoning of the High Court was different.

facts.text: High Court opined that a stone quarry can fall within the category of a mine as defined in the Mines Act of 1952 or the Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It was of the opinion that a stone quarry can fall within the category of a mine as defined in the Mines Act of 1952 or the Mines and Minerals  Regulation and Development  ,Act of 1957.

facts.text: High Court held that the Schedule does not mention either a mine or a stone quarry and item No. 8 cannot be said to be an employment in respect of a mine or stone quarry.

anchor.surface_text: But even so, according to it, the Schedule does number mention either a mine or a stone quarry and item No. 8, viz., Employment in stone breaking and stone crushing, cannot, therefore, be said to be an employment in respect of a mine

facts.text: Certificate granted by the High Court of Judicature at Bombay for appeals to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: These are two appeals by certificate granted by the High Court of Judicature at Bombay against its judgment dated February 4, 1963, in Criminal Appeals Nos. 779 and 780 of 1962.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the quarry is a mine within s. 2(b) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, as stated in Halsburys Laws of England, Third Edition, volume 26, p. 317, the word mine is number a definite term, but is one susceptible of limitation or expansion according to the intention with which it is used.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that stone-breaking or stone-crushing in a quarry is within Entry 8 of the Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: This Court thus read Entry 8 to refer to quarry operations, and we hold that stone-breaking or stone-crushing in a quarry is within the Schedule.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the Inspector was competent to file the complaints.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the Inspector was companypetent to file the companyplaints and the Magistrate and the High Court should number have acquitted the respondent on the ground of his being incompetent to file the companyplaints.

facts.text: Respondent contended that only an inspector appointed by the Maharashtra State was competent to file a complaint.

anchor.surface_text: that the Inspector was number authorised to file the companyplaint and it was only an inspector appointed by the Maharashtra State who was companypetent to file a companyplaint.

facts.text: Magistrate and High Court acquitted the respondent on ground of Inspector's incompetence.
